sentences.sentence: I had been now thirteen days on shore, and had been eleven times on board the ship.
In that time I had brought away all that one pair of hands was able to bring.
The twelfth time to go on board, though I thought I had searched the ship so well that I thought nothing more could be found, I still found about thirty-six pounds worth of money.
I smiled to myself at the sight of( 一看见... ) this money. “What are you good for? You are of no use to me.”
However, upon second thoughts( 经过再次思考 ), I took it away.
I began to think of making another raft( 木筏 ), but, while I was preparing this, the sky grew dark.
The wind began to rise, and in a quarter of an hour started to blow strongly from the shore.
It presently occurred to( 突然想到 ) me, that it was useless to make a raft( 木筏 ) with the wind blowing away from the shore, and so I let myself down into the water, and swam across the channel.
I got home to my little tent, where I felt very secure.
The wind blew very hard all night, and in the next morning when I looked out, the ship gone!
I was surprised, but not too unhappy, since I had already taken almost everything from the ship that might be useful to me.
My thoughts were now entirely directed toward securing myself against either natives, if any should appear, or wild animals.
I had trouble choosing whether I should dig a cave, or set up a tent. I decided to do both.
I soon found that the place where I was was not a healthy or convenient( 方便的 ) place to live, and so I decided to find a better place.
I found a little flat area, on the side of which was a hill that was as steep( 陡峭的 ) as the side of a house.
Here nothing could come down upon( 突然袭击 )  me from the top.
On the one side of the rock there was a hollow( 凹陷的 ) place, like the entrance or door of a cave, but there was not really any cave inside.
On the flat area just in front of this hollow( 凹陷的 ) place, I decided to set up my tent.
Before I set up my tent, I drew a half circle in front of the rock, about ten yards around.
In this half circle I set up two rows of strong poles( 杆 ), none of them more than six inches apart, driving them into the ground till they stood very firm.
Then I took the pieces of thick rope which I had cut from the ship, and laid them in rows between these two rows of poles( 杆 ).
This fence was so strong that neither man nor beast could get into it, or over it.
As an entrance into this place, I made a short ladder to go over the top, so I was completely fenced in, and protected.
Into this tent I brought all my food, and everything that would spoil( 损坏 ) in the rain.
When I had done this, I began to work my way into the rock.
Thus I made a cave just behind my tent, which I could use like a cellar( 地窖 ) for my house.
During the time while I was doing this, I went out once at least every day with my gun, to see if I could kill anything for food.
The first time I went out, I discovered that there were goats in the island, which was a great satisfaction to me.
The first time I shot these creatures I killed a she-goat( 母山羊 ), which had a little baby goat with her.
These two supplied me with meat a great while, for I ate as little as I could.
I had little hope for my situation.
I felt that being cast away( 被...送往（令人不愉快之地） ) on this island was the judgment of Heaven, and that in this lonely place I should end my life.
Many tears would run down my face when I thought like this.
But something always occurred to( 突然想到 ) me that stopped these thoughts.
One day, walking with my gun in my hand, by the seaside, I was thinking about my situation.
It suddenly occurred to( 突然想到 ) me: “Well, you are in a sad situation, it is true.
But remember, where are the others?
Were there not eleven of you in the boat?
Where are the ten?
Why were they not saved and you lost?
Is it better to be here or there?”
Then it occurred to( 突然想到 ) me again, how well I was supplied for my survival.
What would have been my situation if the ship was not driven so near to the shore, and I had not had time to get all these things out of it?
“Particularly,” said I, aloud, though to myself, “what should I have done without a gun?
Or without any tools to make anything, or without clothes, bedding( 寝具 ), a tent or any manner of covering?”
It was, by my estimate( 估计 ), the 30th of September when I first set foot( 登上 ) upon this horrid( 恐怖的 ) island.
After I had been there about ten or twelve days, it came into my thoughts that I should lose my concept of time for lack of books, and pen and ink.
To prevent this, I cut with my knife upon a large post on the shore where I first landed—I came on shore here on the 30th of September, 1659.
Upon the sides of this square post, I made every day a line with my knife, and thus I kept my calendar.
Among the many things which I brought out of the ship, I got several things which I did not mention before.
In particular, pens, ink, and paper, and three or four compasses( 罗盘 ).
Also, I found three very good Bibles( 圣经 ).
And I must not forget that we had in the ship a dog and two cats.
I carried both the cats with me.
As for the dog, he jumped out of the ship, and swam to shore. He gave me all the company I wanted, except for conversation.
But I still wished for more things than I had found, and of these things, ink was one.
While my ink lasted, I kept records very exactly.
But after that was gone I could not make any ink by any means that I could think of.
I also missed having a shovel( 铲子 ) to dig or remove the earth, and needles and thread for clothing.
This lack of tools made everything I did very difficult, and it was nearly a whole year before I had entirely finished my little shelter( 住所 ).
But what concern could I have at the amount of time my tasks took me, since I had enough time to do them?
I now began to consider my situation seriously.
I wrote down the state of my affairs, comparing the comforts I enjoyed against the suffering I endured( 忍受 ), thus:—
Evil( 不幸的事 ): I am cast upon a horrible( 可怕的 ), lonely island, without any hope of recovery.
Good: But I am alive, and not drowned( 淹死的 ), as all my ship’s company were.
Evil( 不幸的事 ): I am divided from mankind, driven away from all human society.
Good: But I am not starved( 挨饿的 ), and dying from lack of food or water.
Evil( 不幸的事 ): I have no one to talk to, or help me.
Good: But God sent the ship in near enough to the shore, and I have got out many necessary things, that will supply my wants( 需求 ) for as long as I live.
On the whole, I still had much to be thankful for.
Having now brought my mind a little to welcome my situation, I began to arrange my way of living, and to make things as easy for myself as I could.
I began to make such necessary things as I found I most wanted, particularly a chair and a table.
I had never handled a tool in my life.
Yet in time, I found that I could make anything I wanted, especially if I had tools.
I made many things even without tools, and some with no more tools than an axe( 斧子 ), which took much labor.
For example, if I wanted a board, I had no other way but to cut down a tree.
I then had to make it flat on either side with my axe( 斧子 ), till it became thin as a board.
I made a table and a chair with short pieces of boards.
I also made large shelves, one over another, all along one side of my cave, to lay all my tools.
And I knocked pieces of metal into the wall of the rock to hang things up.
Having finished my shelter( 住所 ), I began to keep a journal( 日记 ), of which I shall here give you the copy.
I will go on for as long as it lasted, before I was forced to stop writing it when my ink was all used up.
